title: How Hormone Therapy Treats Advanced Prostate Cancer

content: Hormone therapy is a way of treating prostate cancer by cutting off the supply of androgens, or male sex hormones, that cancer cells need to grow. This treatment is also called androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), androgen suppression therapy, or testosterone depleting therapy. Hormone therapy often treats advanced prostate cancer, which is cancer that has spread to other parts of your body or that has come back after treatment. While it won’t cure this type of cancer, hormone therapy can slow down its growth.

content_blocks.text: Hormone therapy is a way of treating prostate cancer by cutting off the supply of androgens, or male sex hormones, that cancer cells need to grow. This treatment is also called androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), androgen suppression therapy, or testosterone depleting therapy. Hormone therapy often treats advanced prostate cancer, which is cancer that has spread to other parts of your body or that has come back after treatment. While it won’t cure this type of cancer, hormone therapy can slow down its growth.

sections.heading: What Are Androgens?
content: Everyone’s bodies make these hormones, but you’ll have more of them if you’re assigned male at birth. The most common androgens are testosterone and dihydrotestosterone. Androgens work in many different ways in your body, including increasing your amount of red blood cells and building strong bones and muscles. But their main job is sexual development. They give men things like a deeper voice and facial hair, and they fuel the growth of prostate cells.

content_blocks.text: Everyone’s bodies make these hormones, but you’ll have more of them if you’re assigned male at birth. The most common androgens are testosterone and dihydrotestosterone. Androgens work in many different ways in your body, including increasing your amount of red blood cells and building strong bones and muscles. But their main job is sexual development. They give men things like a deeper voice and facial hair, and they fuel the growth of prostate cells.

content: Testosterone is mainly made by your testicles, but your adrenal glands make a small amount, and sometimes even prostate cancer cells can, too. Some testosterone gets changed into dihydrotestosterone inside your testicles, prostate gland, and adrenal glands. Hormones that come from your brain control the process. When androgen levels are low, a part of your brain called the hypothalamus releases a chemical called luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LHRH). That signals the nearby pituitary gland to make luteinizing hormone (LH), which, in men, stimulates your testicles to make testosterone.

content_blocks.text: Testosterone is mainly made by your testicles, but your adrenal glands make a small amount, and sometimes even prostate cancer cells can, too. Some testosterone gets changed into dihydrotestosterone inside your testicles, prostate gland, and adrenal glands. Hormones that come from your brain control the process. When androgen levels are low, a part of your brain called the hypothalamus releases a chemical called luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LHRH). That signals the nearby pituitary gland to make luteinizing hormone (LH), which, in men, stimulates your testicles to make testosterone.

sections.heading: How Does Hormone Therapy Work?
content: The most common type of hormone therapy stops your body from making certain hormones. Other treatments keep cancer cells from using androgens as fuel. At first, androgen hormone therapy is usually able to stop prostate cancer from growing. That's because both healthy cells and cancer cells in your prostate need androgens to grow. So this hormone therapy prevents your body from making androgens. The therapy works if you have a type of prostate cancer described as: Androgen dependent Androgen sensitive Castration sensitive Hormone sensitive It’s hard to know how long hormone therapy will control your prostate cancer, but it can work for years.

sections.heading: Tests for prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
content: As time goes on, prostate cancer is usually able to grow even when your androgen levels are very low. This type of prostate cancer is called castration resistant. At that point, you may need to switch to a different type of hormone therapy or try a different treatment altogether. While you’re getting hormone therapy, you’ll have blood tests from time to time. These can test your level of prostate-specific antigen (PSA). PSA is a protein made by both healthy and cancerous prostate cells. Your level usually drops after you start hormone therapy. If it’s rising quickly, it may be a sign that your medication is no longer working, and the cancer has come back or is growing. Learning about the different types of hormone therapy can help you prepare.

content_blocks.text: As time goes on, prostate cancer is usually able to grow even when your androgen levels are very low. This type of prostate cancer is called castration resistant. If it’s rising quickly, it may be a sign that your medication is no longer working, and the cancer has come back or is growing. Learning about the different types of hormone therapy can help you prepare.

sections.heading: Who Gets Hormone Therapy for Prostate Cancer?
content: Hormone therapy is used in several situations. It’s the main treatment to control advanced prostate cancer. Hormone therapy is also offered when lab and imaging tests show that your cancer is likely to grow and spread.

content_blocks.text: Hormone therapy is used in several situations. It’s the main treatment to control advanced prostate cancer. Hormone therapy is also offered when lab and imaging tests show that your cancer is likely to grow and spread.

sections.heading: Types of Hormone Therapy
content: The most common type of hormone therapy used to treat prostate cancer stops your testicles from making testosterone. This can be done in several ways: LHRH agonists These medications can act like a form of LHRH that keeps your brain from releasing it naturally. Then, your pituitary gland stops responding, so it no longer makes LH, and your testicles don’t get the message to make testosterone. LHRH antagonists These medicines block the action of your natural LHRH by keeping the hormone from connecting to receptors in your pituitary gland. Surgery The surgery is called an orchiectomy which removes your testicles to lower testosterone levels. CYP17 inhibitors Because some tissues besides your testicles can make small amounts of testosterone, you might get a type of drug that stops production of the hormone in other places in your body. That’s done by blocking the action of an enzyme – CYP17 – that’s needed for this process. These drugs are also called androgen synthesis inhibitors.

sections.heading: Antiandrogens
content: Some research has found that abiraterone may work better to lower PSA levels in Black men than in White men, and could help them live longer. But Black men are less likely than White men to get this drug or other newer hormone therapy medications. A different type of hormone therapy keeps androgens from reaching prostate cancer cells. This is done with drugs called antiandrogens, androgen receptor blockers, or androgen receptor antagonists. In many cases, doctors recommend a combination approach. You’ll get either an orchiectomy or medication to stop testosterone production, plus a medication to keep any remaining androgens from working.

content_blocks.text: Some research has found that abiraterone may work better to lower PSA levels in Black men than in White men, and could help them live longer. But Black men are less likely than White men to get this drug or other newer hormone therapy medications. A different type of hormone therapy keeps androgens from reaching prostate cancer cells. This is done with drugs called antiandrogens, androgen receptor blockers, or androgen receptor antagonists. In many cases, doctors recommend a combination approach. You’ll get either an orchiectomy or medication to stop testosterone production, plus a medication to keep any remaining androgens from working.

sections.heading: How Hormone Therapy for Prostate Cancer Is Given
content: Some hormone therapy comes as pills you take every day. Others you get as a shot, every month or every few months. You may also get hormone therapy in the form of a small pellet, implanted under the skin in your belly. Surgery to remove your testicles can’t be undone. But with medication-based hormone therapy, your body usually goes back to making androgens if you stop taking the treatment.

content_blocks.text: Some hormone therapy comes as pills you take every day. Others you get as a shot, every month or every few months. You may also get hormone therapy in the form of a small pellet, implanted under the skin in your belly. Surgery to remove your testicles can’t be undone. But with medication-based hormone therapy, your body usually goes back to making androgens if you stop taking the treatment.

sections.heading: How is hormone therapy taken?
content: You might take hormone therapy all the time, or you might have treatment off and on. The two approaches are called continuous and intermittent therapy. Continuous therapy You’ll take medication for the rest of your life or until it stops working. Your body would have reduced androgen production. Intermittent therapy You’ll start and stop hormone therapy, whch allows your body to make androgens again between treatment periods. You might get this therapy on a set schedule, such as several months on, then several months off. Or you could wait to restart your medication once PSA levels start to rise. This gives you a break from possible side effects. What are hormone therapy side efffects? Hormone therapy can come with some side effects. These effects can be very uncomfortable and affect your quality of life. They usually come from the loss of testosterone in your body. Although side effects can be different for each medicine, and for each person, here are some common side effects for hormone therapy.

sections.heading: What's right for me?
content: There’s no scientific agreement on whether continuous or intermittent therapy is best, so talk to your doctor about the pros and cons of each. Also discuss when the best time to start hormone therapy might be for you. You could wait to take medication until you’re having symptoms. Or you could begin as soon as you’re diagnosed with advanced prostate cancer or your PSA levels rise after other treatment. Studies are being done about which approach works best. But you and your doctor will put a cancer treatment plan together that best suits your specific health.

sources: Urology Care Foundation: “Hormone Therapy,” “What is Advanced Prostate Cancer?”
meta_description: Hormone therapy is the main treatment for advanced prostate cancer. Learn what the different options are, and how and when they’re used.
